Well, a part of it is the length of the lens you're allowed the use.
In the Company of Soldiers,"" I was embedded with Dave Petraeus and the 101st Airborne and went with them from Fort Campbell, Kentucky all the way to Baghdad.
And I was at Petraeus' elbow every day all day for a couple of months.
That's really journalism, I think.
And ""An Army at Dawn,"" which is the first volume in a trilogy that I'm writing about the role of the American military in the liberation of Europe in World War II, that's clearly history.
And I think that when you're looking at a 65-year distance, when you've got the wide-angle lens that a historian can use -virtually everything is now unclassified.
All the memoirs have been written.
Most of the principals are dead, certainly all the senior generals.
